intro: Lepidaploa retrosetosa, commonly known as the desert broom, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of North America. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod-like fruits. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Its small, yellow flowers bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Lepidaploa retrosetosa plays a role in stabilizing soil in its native habitat and is often found in desert scrub ecosystems.
